articles.headline: Pawnshops Emerge as Solid Lender in Post-Austerity Spain
articles.snippet: Cajas, or savings banks, have expanded their pawn-brokerage businesses as they seek alternative forms of funding while maintaining their social obligations.
articles.abstract: Cajas, or savings banks, have expanded their pawn-brokerage businesses as they seek alternative forms of funding while maintaining their social obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Lax lending and deadbeat borrowers nearly brought down the Spanish banking system a few years ago. That’s why the remnants of some of the failed banks are resorting to a time-honored form of loans with can’t-miss collateral: pawnshops.

articles.headline: The Tax Sleuth Who Took Down a Drug Lord
articles.snippet: Gary Alford, a tax investigator, was the first to identify the mastermind behind Silk Road, an online drug bazaar, but he was long ignored by law enforcement colleagues.
articles.abstract: Gary Alford, a tax investigator, was the first to identify the mastermind behind Silk Road, an online drug bazaar, but he was long ignored by law enforcement colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gary L. Alford was running on adrenaline when he arrived for work on a Monday in June 2013, at the Drug Enforcement Administration office in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. A tax investigator, he had spent much of the weekend in the living room of his New Jersey townhouse, scrolling through arcane chat rooms and old blog posts, reading on well after his fiancée had gone to sleep.

articles.headline: Hoping for a Price Surge, Oil Companies Keep Wells in Reserve
articles.snippet: Some drilled oil and natural gas wells across the country are currently not producing, but are ready to be tapped quickly if prices begin to rise.
articles.abstract: Some drilled oil and natural gas wells across the country are currently not producing, but are ready to be tapped quickly if prices begin to rise.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERTHOUD, Colo. — The price of oil keeps dropping. But that didn’t stop a work crew from drilling a well recently on what was once a cornfield, carefully guiding the last sections of 13,000 feet of pipe spiraling into the hard Niobrara shale with a diamond-tipped bit.

articles.headline: In Hong Kong, Fears for an Art Museum
articles.snippet: Concerns rise that the Chinese government will hamper the independence needed for a world-class showcase of contemporary works.
articles.abstract: Concerns rise that the Chinese government will hamper the independence needed for a world-class showcase of contemporary works.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At the waterfront site destined for a vast new center for the arts here, the view across Victoria Harbor is one to marvel at — an urban jungle of high-rises that together make up the city’s famous skyline.

articles.headline: As Oil Money Melts, Alaska Mulls First Income Tax in 35 Years
articles.snippet: Falling oil prices have the least-taxed state in the nation facing a budget crisis, and the governor is asking residents to shoulder more of the costs.
articles.abstract: Falling oil prices have the least-taxed state in the nation facing a budget crisis, and the governor is asking residents to shoulder more of the costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Oil money no longer pays the bills here.

articles.headline: The 2-Year Law Education Fails to Take Off
articles.snippet: Created as a way to save students money and help new lawyers get into the job market, one such two-year program closed this fall.
articles.abstract: Created as a way to save students money and help new lawyers get into the job market, one such two-year program closed this fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quicker, cheaper law degree — which got a major vote of confidence when President Obama, a lawyer and former law professor, unexpectedly endorsed it in August 2013 — has been widely promoted  as an ideal way to slash growing student debt and give beginning lawyers a leg up in a difficult job market.

articles.headline: Jet.com’s Strategy: Low Prices, Fast Delivery, Happy Workers
articles.snippet: The start-up’s founder and chief says happiness, in particular the happiness of his employees, will separate his company from ventures that have failed.
articles.abstract: The start-up’s founder and chief says happiness, in particular the happiness of his employees, will separate his company from ventures that have failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can’t accuse Jet.com of timidity.

articles.headline: In Sweden, a Cash-Free Future Nears
articles.snippet: Few places are tilting toward a cashless future as quickly as Sweden, which has become hooked on the convenience of paying by app and plastic.
articles.abstract: Few places are tilting toward a cashless future as quickly as Sweden, which has become hooked on the convenience of paying by app and plastic.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Parishioners text tithes to their churches. Homeless street vendors carry mobile credit-card readers. Even the Abba Museum, despite being a shrine to the 1970s pop group that wrote “Money, Money, Money,” considers cash so last-century that it does not accept bills and coins.

articles.headline: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman
articles.snippet: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.
articles.abstract: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Farkhunda had one chance to escape the mob that wanted to kill her. Two Afghan police officers pulled her onto the roof of a low shed, above the angry crowd.

articles.headline: As Graduation Rates Rise, Experts Fear Diplomas Come Up Short
articles.snippet: The number of students completing high school has reached historic peaks, yet other measures of academic readiness for college or jobs are much lower.
articles.abstract: The number of students completing high school has reached historic peaks, yet other measures of academic readiness for college or jobs are much lower.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — A sign in a classroom here at Berea High School, northwest of downtown in the largest urban district in the state, sends this powerful message: “Failure Is Not an Option. You Will Pass. You Will Learn. You Will Succeed.”

articles.headline: India Offers Atypical Video Challenges
articles.snippet: Both local entertainment companies, as well as Netflix, Amazon and 21st Century Fox, hope to persuade Indians to pay for online streaming, but changing current habits will be difficult.
articles.abstract: Both local entertainment companies, as well as Netflix, Amazon and 21st Century Fox, hope to persuade Indians to pay for online streaming, but changing current habits will be difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — As the morning rain dripped in the garden outside, the yoga teacher Aparajita Jamwal got down on one knee, stretching the other leg behind her in a lunge known as the equestrian pose.

articles.headline: State-Level Brawls Over Medicaid Reflect Divide in G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Many Republican governors support expanding coverage through the Affordable Care Act, a law that members of Congress from their party want to see fail.
articles.abstract: Many Republican governors support expanding coverage through the Affordable Care Act, a law that members of Congress from their party want to see fail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Thune of South Dakota, the No. 3 Republican in the Senate, voted earlier this month to repeal major provisions of the Affordable Care Act and to end its expansion of Medicaid, arguing that the health law was “unpopular and unaffordable.”

articles.headline: How Hillary Clinton Went Undercover to Examine Race in Education
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s work, as a young law student in 1972, to determine whether an Alabama school discriminated against blacks was a moment of awakening for her.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s work, as a young law student in 1972, to determine whether an Alabama school discriminated against blacks was a moment of awakening for her.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOTHAN, Ala. — On a humid summer day in 1972, Hillary Rodham walked into this town’s new private academy, a couple of cinder-block classrooms erected hurriedly amid fields of farmland, and pretended to be someone else.

articles.headline: Rahm Emanuel, Under Siege in Chicago, Shows Contrite Side
articles.snippet: A debate over race and policing has swept through many cities this year, but its arrival in Chicago has pointed an especially strong spotlight on City Hall.
articles.abstract: A debate over race and policing has swept through many cities this year, but its arrival in Chicago has pointed an especially strong spotlight on City Hall.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — GQ, the men’s magazine, just named Mayor Rahm Emanuel to its list of “The Worst People of 2015.” In Springfield, the Illinois capital, a fellow Democrat is pressing for a measure to permit Mr. Emanuel’s recall from office. And here, demonstrators bearing thousands of signatures last week demanded Mr. Emanuel’s resignation, then blocked traffic on Christmas Eve along the city’s glittering North Michigan Avenue shopping district, chanting, “Rahm’s got to go in 2016!”

articles.headline: F.A.A. Drone Laws Start to Clash With Stricter Local Rules
articles.snippet: As the Federal Aviation Administration begins to assert its authority to regulate drones, local lawmakers contend the agency’s efforts do not go far enough in protecting privacy and public safety.
articles.abstract: As the Federal Aviation Administration begins to assert its authority to regulate drones, local lawmakers contend the agency’s efforts do not go far enough in protecting privacy and public safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Frank Carollo, a longtime member of the City Council here, had worked for several weeks fine-tuning a proposal to limit the use of recreational drones, the increasingly popular remote-controlled flying devices. Minutes before the start of the vote on the rules this month, lawyers from the Federal Aviation Administration called him.

articles.headline: Mattel Takes a Risk, With Barbie and Bugs
articles.snippet: Toy Box, a division of Mattel, developed the Bug Racer and other ambitious projects as part of its mandate to fast-track promising, experimental toys.
articles.abstract: Toy Box, a division of Mattel, developed the Bug Racer and other ambitious projects as part of its mandate to fast-track promising, experimental toys.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Gerry Cody, a senior design manager at Mattel, cheerfully loaded a live cricket into the driver’s seat of a new toy car, the cricket probably did not have time to wonder how it had gotten to this point.

articles.headline: In Hollywood, a Year of Mining the Past for Box-Office Gold
articles.snippet: Hollywood is on track to set a domestic box-office record for 2015, largely with the help of sequels like the latest “Star Wars” and “Jurassic Park” films.
articles.abstract: Hollywood is on track to set a domestic box-office record for 2015, largely with the help of sequels like the latest “Star Wars” and “Jurassic Park” films.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” took in about $153.5 million in North America over the weekend, for an estimated $545 million total since opening in mid-December, putting Hollywood in position to set a full-year domestic box-office record.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Questions on Direction of a Paper in Las Vegas
articles.snippet: Billionaires buying newspapers isn’t new, but Sheldon Adelson’s ownership of The Las Vegas Review-Journal raises concerns about the paper’s direction.
articles.abstract: Billionaires buying newspapers isn’t new, but Sheldon Adelson’s ownership of The Las Vegas Review-Journal raises concerns about the paper’s direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until a few weeks ago, Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino mogul and Republican party benefactor, was better known for suing newspapers than owning them.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Sydney Ember

articles.headline: Obama’s ‘Boots on the Ground’: U.S. Special Forces Are Sent to Tackle Global Threats
articles.snippet: While President Obama has said he opposes sending Americans to fight in far-flung countries, his administration carves out exceptions for Special Operations.
articles.abstract: While President Obama has said he opposes sending Americans to fight in far-flung countries, his administration carves out exceptions for Special Operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They are taking on a larger combat role in Afghanistan, where the war was supposed to be over. They are headed to Syria to help fight the Islamic State in its stronghold. And President Obama recently ordered nearly 300 of them to Cameroon to assist African troops in their battle against a militant group that has pledged loyalty to the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Remembering Alan Kurdi: Syrian Family’s Tragedy Goes Beyond Image of Boy on Beach
articles.snippet: The death of Alan Kurdi, 2, which focused the world on refugees, was just one chapter of a sprawling family’s story in its desperate attempts to escape Syria and find a new home.
articles.abstract: The death of Alan Kurdi, 2, which focused the world on refugees, was just one chapter of a sprawling family’s story in its desperate attempts to escape Syria and find a new home.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Friday is the first anniversary of the death of Alan Kurdi, a 2-year-old Syrian refugee whose drowned body was discovered on a beach in Turkey. Photos of the boy shocked the world and put a human face on the refugee crisis. Since then hundreds of children have died in the fighting in Syria and on the refugee trail. Anne Barnard, The Times’ Beirut Bureau chief who leads our coverage in Syria, reported on Alan’s death and his sprawling family’s attempts to escape worn-torn Syria. This article originally ran on Dec. 27, 2015.

articles.headline: Japan and South Korea Settle Dispute Over Wartime ‘Comfort Women’
articles.snippet: The deal, in which Japan made an apology and promised an $8.3 million payment, may help mend ties between the countries.
articles.abstract: The deal, in which Japan made an apology and promised an $8.3 million payment, may help mend ties between the countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — More than 70 years after the end of World War II, South Korea and Japan reached a landmark agreement on Monday to resolve their dispute over Korean women who were forced to serve as sex slaves for Japan’s Imperial Army.

articles.headline: T.S.A. Moves Closer to Rejecting Some State Driver’s Licenses for Travel
articles.snippet: The Department of Homeland Security said airport screeners may soon start accepting only licenses that meet federal standards, despite resistance from privacy advocates.
articles.abstract: The Department of Homeland Security said airport screeners may soon start accepting only licenses that meet federal standards, despite resistance from privacy advocates.
articles.lead_paragraph: As soon as next year, a driver’s license may no longer be enough for airline passengers to clear security in some states, if the Department of Homeland Security has its way.

articles.headline: Iraqi Victory Over ISIS in Ramadi Could Prove Pivotal
articles.snippet: The militants fled the western city’s government headquarters, although pockets of resistance remained in the north and east.
articles.abstract: The militants fled the western city’s government headquarters, although pockets of resistance remained in the north and east.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Breaking a seven-month occupation by the Islamic State, Iraqi troops on Monday retook most of Ramadi, the most populous city in western Iraq, overrunning a government compound held by the terrorist group at the city center and dealing a setback to its deadly grip on large parts of the country.
articles.byline: By Falih Hassan and Sewell Chan
